child.pub-comments: "Ross finds one piece of evidence for a sizable South-east Papuan group, consisting of Dagan, Mailuan, Yareba, Manubaran, Kwalean, and Koiari but excluding Binandere" (Pawley 2005: 94).

child.pub-comments: "There is no 'Brahman' subgroup: Faita is reassigned to the Josephstaal subgroup of Madang; Biyom and Tauya are reassigned to the Rai Coast subgroup; and Isabi is excluded from Madang and reassigned to the Goroka subgroup" (Pawley 2005: 93).

child.pub-comments: "… The Kalam-Kobon group is included in Madang (it was formly assigned to Wurm's East New Guinea Highlands micro-phylum (a group that itself is no longer recognised)" (Pawley 2005: 93).

"With about 100 members, Madang is the largest subgroup that can be justified in terms of shared innovations" (Pawley 2005: 93). "… The Madang group is divided into four major branches: (a) South Adelbert Range, (b) Croisilles (roughly corresponding to Z'graggen's 'North Adelbert Range', plus 'Mabuso' groups), (c) Rai Coast, and (d) Kalam-Kobon" (Pawley 2005: 93).

child.pub-comments: "Two well-defined groups are located in the Eastern Highlands, now generally termed Kainantu and Goroka groups. These have long been tentatively placed together in a subgroup" (Pawley 2005: 94).

child.pub-comments: "Central and South New Guinea as defined by Voorhoeve (1968) and McElhanon and Vorhoeve (1970) is almost certainly not a valid subgroup. Indeed, Voorhoeve proposed it as a family of (in some cases very remotely) related languages, not as a subgroup. However, we can also be fairly optimistic about validating a sizeable subgroup that includes at least Ok, Awyu-Dumut and Asmat-Kamoro groups, as suggested by Voorhoeve (1968). I will call this putative group Central and South-west New Guinea" (Pawley 2005: 94).

child.pub-comments: "Although we provisionally assign the Kiwai group to the TNG phylum on lexical grounds, the evidence at present is slender" (Pawley 2005: 92).
